thread.title: $A plunges more than 1pc, edging closer to US69¢
thread.title_full: $A plunges more than 1pc, edging closer to US69¢ | afr.com

author: John Kehoe
title: $A plunges more than 1pc, edging closer to US69¢
text:
The dollar fell as low as US70.16¢ in morning trade in New York. Getty Images Concerns are mounting that the Australian economy may have shrunk in the June quarter , ahead of gross domestic product figures due to be published on Wednesday.
The Australian dollar recovered slightly to be fetching around US70.31¢ around 5am AEST on Wednesday.
Thierry Wizman, global foreign exchange and interest rate strategist at Macquarie Group in New York, said the sharp selloff in the Australian dollar was due to concern about China's economy.
"It's not even about growth in China any more, it's more about whether policy is being managed coherently and effectively by policymakers in China," Mr Wizman said.
China's manufacturing sector activity slumped to a three-year low in August, according to Chinese government data. The government is trying to crack down on traders seeking to deliberately drive shares lower.
Credit Suisse global head of foreign exchange strategy Shahab Jalinoos attributed the Australian dollar's fall to a "risk off" trading day in global markets and the Reserve Bank of Australia's commentary about softness in China.
"There are still downside risks to Australia from external sources which is probably a negative for the currency," Mr Jalinoos said.
Share indexes on Wall Street fell almost 3 per cent on Tuesday. Commodity currencies like the South African rand, Mexican peso, Brazillian real and Canadian dollar were also sold off.
China is Australia's largest trading partner and a big buyer of mining commodities including iron ore and coal.
Australia's current account deficit blew out to $19 billion in the June quarter , from $13.5 billion.
Iron ore exports fell 8 per cent - or by $1.6 billion - in the June quarter, with volumes down 2 per cent and prices down 6 per cent, the Australian Bureau of Statistics said on Tuesday. Coal exports dived 11 per cent, with volumes down 8 per cent and prices 4 per cent lower.
In China, the official Purchasing Managers Index declined to 49.7 last month, down from 50 in July.
Kathy Lien, BK Asset Management managing director of foreign exchange said "it's all about China", when asked to explain the ongoing weakness in the Australian currency.
The Chinese slowdown appears to be knocking on to neighbouring markets. Economic activity in Japan and South Korea was also weaker than expected.
South Korea said on Tuesday that its exports had fallen 14.7 per cent in August, the most in six years.
The Reserve Bank of Australia kept the overnight interest rate steady at 2 per cent on Tuesday .
Reserve Bank governor Glenn Stevens noted there had been "some further softening" in conditions in China and east Asia of late, but stronger US growth.
The Australian dollar was little changed soon after the decision was announced on Tuesday afternoon in Sydney, trading at US71.40¢, before the plunge overnight.
